content.heading: Dreamt Into Existence.
content.paragraphs: When the great beholder Cephanox was cast out into the astral sea by a group of upstart adventurers, he was left with naught to do but sleep. In his endless slumber, he dreamt the world of Omnaeus into existence; it is a place of endless stories, manifested dreams, and inescapable nightmares.

content.heading: Axiomatic Force.
content.paragraphs: A conductor is one of the highest ranking officers in the Axiomatic hierarchy, and there are only eight known conductors in existence. Conductors are vital to the functionality of the entire Axiomatic Hivemind, and their primary responsibility is to gather energy, which they transmit to the rest of the Hivemind via an electromagnetic field. A conductor always acts within the best interests of the Hivemind. It knows no morals or mercy, and it may gather this energy from any source that will produce it. Conductors typically seek out areas where immensely powerful beings dwell or where major events are taking place, where they then extract energy with frightening precision and efficiency.

content.heading: Circuit of Life.
content.paragraphs: Life is one of the most efficient sources of energy, and conductors are exceptionally well-equipped to take it. Behemoths that would threaten entire cities may be felled by a single conductor, who acts with perfect planning and has an encyclopedic knowledge of seemingly every creature in Omnaeus. A report from Guinn that was written by members of the Axiomatic Hivemind stated that conductors are so ruthless in their extraction of energy that they may even remove all memory of a being's existence in the process. Scholars speculate that conductors may be the primary cause of death in celestial societies, though no one can know for certain if conductors are capable of such summary destruction because there are no recorded incidents of anything being erased from history.

passives.name: Constant Repairs
passives.effect: At the start of the conductor's turn, the conductor regains 11 (1d12 + 5) hit points.

passives.name: One of a Kind
passives.effect: The conductor has a unique feature depending on which of the eight conductors it is.

passives.name: Purge
passives.effect: Whenever one of the conductor's features recharges, the conductor can choose a creature within 50 feet. The target must succeed on a DC 19 Dexterity saving throw or take 11 (1d12 + 5) lightning damage. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage.

actions.name: Rapier
actions.effect:
Melee Weapon 
 
 Attack: 1d20+11 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. 
 
 Hit: 9 (1d8 + 5) piercing damage.

actions.name:
Brutal Flurry 
 (Recharge 5-6)
actions.effect: As an action, the conductor makes ten rapier attacks. These attacks ignore all resistances and immunities.

actions.name:
Disarming Flourish 
 (Recharge 5-6)
actions.effect: As an action, the conductor makes a disarm attack against a creature within 5 feet who is wielding a melee weapon. If the attack is successful, the conductor picks up the weapon and makes five attacks with it. The conductor then makes a ranged weapon attack with it against a target within 100 feet, as if the weapon has the thrown property.

actions.name:
Orbital Suplex 
 (Recharge 5-6)
actions.effect: As an action, the conductor makes a grapple attack against a creature within 5 feet. If the grapple is successful, the target is restrained until the start of the conductor's next turn, and the conductor's Phase feature recharges. While the target is restrained by this feature, the target moves with the conductor whenever the conductor moves. A creature restrained by this feature can be freed if it or another creature within 5 feet takes an action to make a DC 19 Athletics check and succeeds.

bonus-actions.name: Rapid Update
bonus-actions.effect: As a bonus action, the conductor changes its speed to be walking, burrowing, climbing, flying, or swimming speed.

bonus-actions.name:
Overload 
 (Recharge 5-6)
bonus-actions.effect: As a bonus action, the conductor gains an additional use of its action.

bonus-actions.name:
Recharge 
 (Recharge 5-6)
bonus-actions.effect: As a bonus action, the conductor recharges all of its recharge abilities.

reactions.name:
Firewall 
 (Recharge 5-6)
reactions.effect: As a reaction, the conductor adds its proficiency bonus to its AC for a turn.

reactions.name:
Phase 
 (Recharge 5-6)
reactions.effect: As a free reaction, the conductor teleports up to 80 feet in any direction.

content.heading: Incomplete Dreams
content.paragraphs: Nightcrawlers are incomplete ideas, and their misshapen, unnatural forms are a clear indication of their uselessness. When a lucid dream is interrupted prematurely, errant thoughts of strangers and acquaintances escape into reality, manifesting from the mind's failed recreations of humans. Only the most basic shape of a humanoid is realized; a nightcrawler is nothing more than a lump of flesh upon two legs.

content.heading: Soul Searchers.
content.paragraphs: Nightcrawlers spend all of their functionally useless existences tirelessly wandering about, their wobbly legs carrying them across countless miles. A nightcrawler seeks solely to complete itself, which it can only accomplish by absorbing ideas from sentient beings. As a nightcrawler feasts upon the thoughts of those around it, it will slowly shift and change to match those thoughts, forming into another living being. With intense focus and time, one who discovers a nightcrawler could effectively turn it into any creature that one desires, but only those with the keenest minds may fully develop it into another intelligent being.

content.heading: Always Unique.
content.paragraphs: As a result of their origins, nightcrawlers are wildly inconsistent. They can vary in size and shape tremendously, but they are almost always humanoid. As a nightcrawler absorbs thoughts, it grows in size until it is large enough to transform into something else.

content.heading: Mindless Followers.
content.paragraphs: As a result of their desire to be completed, nightcrawlers always seek to follow a master. Small nightcrawlers often follow larger nightcrawlers in groups, as if they are children following their parents. However, nightcrawlers will always follow sentient creatures if there are any nearby. Nightcrawlers are completely blind to everything except thoughts, so they will always pursue those with the most creative minds. In the rare event that a nightcrawler absorbs enough ideas to become sentient, it will express its deepest devotions to the one who shaped it and follow its master's will without question.

passives.name: Growth Mindset
passives.effect: Whenever the nightcrawler increases its Dexterity modifier by 1, its AC increases by 1. Whenever the nightcrawler increases its Strength modifier by 1, its attack and damage bonuses for thump attacks increase by 1.

passives.name: Psionic Aura
passives.effect: Any sentient creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the nightcrawler must succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw or take 2 (1d4) psychic damage.

passives.name: Thought Conglomerate
passives.effect: Whenever the nightcrawler deals psychic damage to a sentient creature, one of its lowest ability scores (chosen randomly) increases by 1. The nightcrawler completely transforms into another creature when its Constitution score is increased by this effect, maintaining its ability scores and any missing hit points.

actions.name: Thought Absorb
actions.effect:
Melee Weapon 
 
 Attack: +3 to hit, reach 30 ft., one creature. 
 
 Hit: 3 (1d4 + 1) psychic damage

actions.name: Thump
actions.effect:
Melee Weapon 
 
 Attack: +0 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. 
 
 Hit: 0 (1d4 = 2) bludgeoning damage

content.heading: Clockwork Servants.
content.paragraphs: The kingdom of Guinn was established around the Major Key, a massive clockwork key that rotates the Inner Machinations. The Axos Legion tends to those who live there, under strict orders to protect and tend to the needs of those with noble blood. In return, the nobles promise to protect the clockwork key from any who would harm it. However, due to the Axos Legion automating countless things, the rulers of Guinn are generally incompetent, but nobody cares because the clockworks handle everything.

content.heading: Pervasive Boredom.
content.paragraphs: Conflict in Guinn is a rarity, and the people will actively put themselves in danger, if only to experience something more thrilling than a life of endless luxury. Many nobles in Guinn have taken to practicing dark, forbidden arts, practicing rhetoric with fiends and sending them against their own armies. The clockworks are indifferent to their masters' actions, and the ensuing battles between devils and machines are viewed as a source of entertainment, with nobles often going to war with one another simply for bragging rights.

content2.location: Northern Hemisphere, around the Major Key

content.heading: The Axiomatic Hivemind.
content.paragraphs: The Axiomatic Hivemind exists deep within the crust of Omnaeus. It is a force of pure constants that binds the chaos of the planet together. In great underground chasms, massive continental-sized gears known as the Inner Machinations turn at a constant rate, tended to by the Axos Legion. The Axos Legion are an army of self-replicating clockworks who operate according to the Grand Design, a set of fundamental rules that was written during the birth of Omnaeus. The exact rulings of the Grand Design are unknown to any but the Axos Legion, but one can extrapolate based on their behavior. One thing is clear: the gears must always turn.

content.heading: Planetary Change.
content.paragraphs: As the gears turn, the northern and southern hemispheres of the planet twist around each other, as if the planet is split evenly from east to west. Anything that would connect the two halves of the planet that is not part of the Inner Machinations is quickly torn asunder as the planet rotates with unfathomable force around a rift known as the Fissure. The planet simultaneously rotates as a whole along an inconsistent, tilted axis that exposes different parts of the planet to various amounts of light from Omnaeus’s sun, which is known as the Sunspot. The Sunspot remains stationary. From Omnaeus, it appears to be a great bright ring in the sky, as its center is darker than the rest of it.

content.heading: Interdimensional Ogre
content.paragraphs:
Grorg is a nice ogre who guards both sides of a bridge across the river at once, believing that he is protecting travelers from a cruel ogre who waits on the other side. 
 A time anomaly prevents Grorg from ever crossing the bridge to meet his other self.

content.heading: Tears of the Celestials.
content.paragraphs: An ore of purest brilliance, prismati is said to be the tears of the celestials themselves. When the celestial wars cracked the sky, they sent a shower of brilliance down upon Omnaeus. Prismati is the concentrated essence of all of the faith held by a particular celestial, released at once in a solid form as a celestial undergoes true death. It is unknown what use it may serve, but its very nature makes it irresistible to most.

content.heading: Irresistible Brilliance.
content.paragraphs:
Upon seeing prismati, a creature must make a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw. On a success, a creature is immune to this effect for the next hour. On a failure, a creature feels compelled to acquire and possess the prismati for the next hour. A compelled creature will do what it can to acquire the prismati, but it will not do anything that it would never do otherwise, such as harming a loved one. 
 
 This primati holds the essence of Trixan, a trickster celestial god who seeks to return to the Brainstorm.

content.heading: Effects
content.paragraphs:
Upon drawing a card from this deck of cards, the fate of the drawer is forever shifted. Only one drawn card may take effect per person. 
 
 Crown: You have friends in high places. Some choice knowledge will come your way from the master of this realm 
 Sun: The world revolves around you. The gods would like your attention. 
 Moon: You are attuned to the world’s greatest mysteries. You will experience what others do not. 
 Star: You are a beacon of hope, warmth, and radiance. Others will rally to your cause. 
 Comet: You are a fleeting rarity. Your actions will not go unnoticed. 
 The Fates: The master of this realm will consult with you 
 Throne: You command an aura of importance. You deserve more. 
 Key: The world is open to you. You will know the way. 
 Knight: You have been chosen. Guard the Deck, and it will grant you a boon. 
 Gem: You are valuable. You will be protected and cherished. 
 Talons: The claws dig in. You are restricted, but you know not how. 
 Void: You are nothing. You will be treated as such. 
 Flames: Your world will burn around you. A devil delights in your suffering. 
 Skull: Death would like to make a deal. 
 Idiot: Nothing has changed. 
 Dungeon: The world is a dangerous place. You may encounter traps wherever you go. 
 Ruin: Your greatest achievements will lie in shambles. Your name will be forever besmirched. 
 Euryale: Fear can be petrifying. In crucial moments, you will fail. 
 Rogue: Trust is a dangerous thing. You will be betrayed. 
 Balance: All must remain in alignment. Your actions will have equal and opposite reactions. 
 Fool: You know not what you are. You are prone to delusion. 
 Jester: The world laughs behind your back. You are difficult to take seriously.

content.heading: Properties
content.paragraphs:
Two-Handed, Heavy 
 2d6 Bludgeoning

content.heading: Effects
content.paragraphs:
You have a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this magic weapon. 
 
 When you hit with a melee attack using this magic maul and reduce the target to 0 hit points, you gain 2d6 temporary hit points.

Dreamcatchers attune themselves to the Astral Plane, embracing the unpredictability of nature in an attempt to fully tame it. True fishermen at heart, Dreamcatchers aspire to find and conquer the rarest creatures throughout the planes. They seek to accomplish this through mastery of an astral lure, a magical fishing line capable of traversing the planes and bringing back anything it hooks onto.

content.heading: Dreamcatcher Magic
content.paragraphs:
3rd-level dreamcatcher feature 
 
 You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Dreamcatcher Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

content.heading: Astral Lure
content.paragraphs:
3rd-level dreamcatcher feature 
 
 You're attuned to a magical fishing line. You can use an action and expend one spell slot to cast your Astral Lure, summoning a random creature of a CR less than or equal to your character level from any plane of existence. For each spell level higher than 1st, you may see the creature that you are summoning before it is summoned, cancel the summoning, and start the summoning process over. 
 
 Before casting the lure, you may magically bait it, choosing the monster type of the creature that you would like to summon. When casting the lure, roll a die from 1 to your character level. The value rolled is the CR of the creature that is summoned. Also, roll a d100. On a 1, the creature's CR is doubled. On a 100, the lure summons a random uncommon magical item instead

content.heading: Master Fisherman
content.paragraphs: 3rd-level dreamcatcher feature You know how to use your fishing skills in combat, which grants you the following benefits. Spectral Hook. Whenever you hit a creature with a ranged weapon attack, the target is hooked by a spectral fishing line. Whenever a hooked creature moves 1 foot, it spends 2 feet of movement. It remains hooked until it is freed by a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check against your spell save DC. A creature can use an action or spend half of its speed to attempt this check. You can only have one creature hooked at a time, and you cannot use your Astral Lure while you have a creature hooked. As an item interaction, you can free a creature that you have hooked. Reel In. As either an Attack action or a bonus action, you pull a creature that you have hooked up to 10 feet closer to you. The creature takes 1d4 magical slashing damage. If you used an action, the creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC or be knocked prone. Cast Out. As an Attack action, you target a creature that you have hooked. The target is freed from being hooked and is launched 1d6 x 5 feet in a direction of your choice. The distance that the target travels is rolled after you choose the direction. The target must then succeed on a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC or be knocked prone.

content.heading: Off the Hook
content.paragraphs:
7th-level dreamcatcher feature 
 
 You've mastered your ability to contend with a single, struggling opponent. When a creature that you have hooked with your astral fishing line is about to make an attack, you can use Cast Out as a reaction before the attack is made

content.heading: Ascendant Angler
content.paragraphs: 11th-level Dreamcatcher feature You have a technique for catching nearly any foe, which grants you the following benefits. Catch of the Day. You can now have the same creature hooked multiple times. Whenever a creature would be freed from being hooked, it is instead freed from only one hook. Whenever you target a creature with Reel In or Cast Out, you can repeat the same effect on the same creature for each additional hook that it is hooked by. No Escape. Your ranged weapon attacks weave in and out of the Astral Plane as they are made, allowing for them to pass through solid materials. Your ranged weapon attacks ignore all benefits provided by total cover or less. When you use Reel In or Cast Out, you can pull or launch the target directly through solid materials. If this ability causes a creature to occupy the same space as a solid object, the creature moves to the closest available space. Plenty of Fish. You can now have an unlimited number of creatures hooked at the same time. Whenever you use Reel In or Cast Out, you can target up to all of the creatures that you have hooked at once.

content.heading: Binding Constellation
content.paragraphs:
15th-level dreamcatcher feature 
 
 You can trap enemies in an astral net. As an action, you can deploy a number of tethers up to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of three tethers), placing each of them in different spaces within 20 feet of you. These tethers last until this feature can be used again, at which point they dissipate. 
 
 As a bonus action, you can move a tether that is within 20 feet of you to another space within 20 feet of you. 
 
 All of the tethers are connected to each other by ethereal walls of magical energy that are 5 feet high and 1 foot thick. Whenever a creature of your choice starts its turn while surrounded by these walls on at least three sides, it must make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, it is restrained until the start of its next turn. 
 
 Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short rest.

You are your own patron. You follow the written word, the binding force, and the eternal promise. Your power does not come from a being, but an idea. The ideals that you serve are your own to decide, but make no mistake. The written word cannot be undone, and you bear the responsibility of ensuring that your contracts are upheld, lest the cosmos marks you a liar. Make your deals well, talk fast, buy low, sell high, get every detail on paper, and the Contract shall reward you. Should you succumb to chaos and fail to come out on top, expect no mercy from the Contract, for you'll have written your own fate.

content.heading: Expanded Spell List
content.paragraphs: The Contract lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

content.heading: Compelling Declaration
content.paragraphs: 1st-level Contract feature Your familiarity with the power of words grants you the following benefits. Imposing Confidence. You act with such confidence that even your enemies expect you to succeed. Whenever you make an attack roll, you can use your Charisma modifier for the attack and damage rolls instead of its typical modifier. Wordsmith. You know how to utilize the spiritual cosmos to enact certain rites of power. You can cast the ceremony spell at will, without expending a spell slot or material components. When you cast the spell, you may choose to perform this rite instead: Contract: You write a contract and have it willingly signed by all creatures that it names. If a creature signs a contract while it is under the effects of a mind-altering spell, or while it does not agree to the terms of the contract, the spell fails. If not every creature that a contract names signs it, the spell fails. A single clause of a contract must consist of an activity that a named creature must do, to the best of their ability, should a condition be met within a specified timeframe. If this condition is met, that creature has a specified amount of time to do that activity. If a creature runs out of time to do an activity as is stated in the contract, that creature loses all agency and immediately begins to fulfill the conditions of the contract as they normally would, as if they had decided to do so on their own. A creature that has lost its agency in this way is fully conscious, but has no control over what it says or does. A contract may consist of any number of clauses, but clauses that do not satisfy the listed requirements do nothing. Once a contract has been signed by all creatures that it names, its meaning is interpreted literally according to the words that are written on it. If the meaning of a clause is logically ambiguous, the clause does nothing. If any of the creatures that signed a contract die or the contract itself is destroyed, the contract loses all of its power and does nothing.

content.heading: Up the Ante
content.paragraphs: 1st-level Contract feature You know how to bargain for power, and you can invest in your own success to earn even more, granting you the following benefits. Ante Dice. You have a pool of d4s that are known as your ante dice. The number of dice in the pool equals 1 + your warlock level. Your pool regains all expended dice when you finish a long rest. Whenever you make an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw that uses your Charisma modifier, you may choose to spend one of your ante dice to add a d4 to the roll. You can do so after seeing the initial roll but before any of the roll's effects occur. Bountiful Returns. Whenever one of your ante dice is rolled, if the affected roll changes from a failure to a success, you regain an ante die. Risky Investment. Whenever an ante die is about to be rolled, you can choose to spend any number of ante dice prior to the roll. All of the ante dice that you spent are also rolled, and the result is the sum of all of the ante dice minus the number of ante dice that were rolled. If you roll a one on any of the ante dice, all of the ante dice that you spent have no effect.

content.heading: Unbridled Jurisdiction
content.paragraphs: 6th-level Contract feature Your devotion to semantics causes you to emit an aura of objectivity that you are unable to control. The effects of the zone of truth spell are centered on you at all times.

content.heading: Aspiring Entrepreneur
content.paragraphs: 6th-level Contract feature You know how to invest your power in others, allowing you to profit off of their successes and failures alike using a variety of strategies. You gain the following benefits. Life Insurance. As a bonus action, you spend an ante die and choose a creature that you can see. The next time the target makes a saving throw, the ante die is rolled, and the result is added to the roll. This effect lasts for one round. Pyramid Scheme. As a bonus action, you spend an ante die and choose a creature that you can see. The next time the target makes an attack roll, the ante die is rolled, and the result is added to the roll. Whenever an ante die is rolled using this ability, if the affected roll is a success, the target can apply this effect to two other creatures it can see. Each instance of this effect lasts for one round. Whenever you are targeted by this effect, the effect does nothing, and you regain an ante die instead. Your Bountiful Returns ability does not apply to this ability. Short Sell. As a bonus action, you spend an ante die and choose a creature that you can see. The next time the target makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw, the ante die is rolled, and the result is subtracted from the roll. This effect lasts for one round. Whenever an ante die is rolled for this ability, if the affected roll is a failure, you regain an ante die.

content.heading: Corporate Raider
content.paragraphs: 10th-level Contract feature You're powerful enough that you can aggressively dominate the market, taking advantage of weaker competitors to further your own gains. You gain the following benefits. Optimized Workflow. When a creature you can see is about to make an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw, you can spend an ante die to use one of your Aspiring Entrepreneur abilities as a reaction. Reap What You Sow. Whenever you make a damage roll, you can spend an ante die to add it to your roll. You regain hit points equal to the result of the ante die. Undercut. After a creature you can see makes a damage roll, you can spend an ante die to remove the highest damage die that was rolled.

content.heading: Soul Proprietor
content.paragraphs: 14th-level Contract feature You're well-recognized as a patron of power, and you have all of the influence that comes with the title. You gain the following benefits. Influential Presence. You can choose which creatures are affected by your Unbridled Jurisdiction feature. Self-Promotion. Your ante dice turn into d6s. When you use your Risky Investment feature, you subtract two from the result for each ante die that you spend instead of one. Tax Refund. As a bonus action, you regain all of the ante dice that you spent on the previous round. You can't use this ability again until you finish a short or long rest.
